pull.title: doc: Document ALLOW_HOST_PACKAGES dependency option
pull.body: Provided entry in depends, README.md to ensure that ALLOW_HOST_PACKAGES dependency option is documented, #19113

events.body:
@skmcontrib Thank you for working on it.

cc @dongcarl

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* #18077 (net: Add NAT-PMP port forwarding support by hebasto)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

@skmcontrib 
Mind rebasing and addressing reviewers' comments?
@hebasto @dongcarl @laanwj Thanks for your review comments. I have incorporated all the changes.
Please squash your commits according to https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#squashing-commits

@hebasto The earlier squash I did merged all my previous commits into a single commit. So now there are two commits - a squashed commit (e8c3e2bef) and also a merge commit(e4946cbcf). I'm having some trouble squashing these two. Maybe I don't understand this fully. Any pointers? Also as suggested in the contributing guidelines I have enabled "allow edits from maintainers". Sorry for the trouble and thanks for the help.

@skmcontrib 
> @hebasto The earlier squash I did merged all my previous commits into a single commit. So now there are two commits - a squashed commit ([e8c3e2b](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/e8c3e2befc2d8cdfcdb2bd3b92ce71c6affefe4a)) and also a merge commit([e4946cb](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/e4946cbcf9d1ff310df3d1cd929346d96ed059a0)). I'm having some trouble squashing these two. Maybe I don't understand this fully. Any pointers? Also as suggested in the contributing guidelines I have enabled "allow edits from maintainers". Sorry for the trouble and thanks for the help.

You could start from [this GitHub guide](https://guides.github.com/introduction/flow/).

Your [working branch](https://github.com/skmcontrib/bitcoin/commits/allowHostDoc) in your [forked repo](https://github.com/skmcontrib/bitcoin) should contain no merge commits. Only commits with your changes, that are based on "master" branch at some point, are allowed. The merge commit is made by a maintainer when your working branch is merged into this repo "master" branch.

"allow edits from maintainers" allows maintainers to edit PR's title and posts. It is a contributor's burden to keep his own working branch in ready-to-merge state.
@hebasto incorporated all the review comments. Thanks

ACK 47e2a35fac9951c125b784a9d14027338c56c750.

nit: it appears that back quoting doesn't work within `<dd> ... </dd>`, therefore it could be dropped

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -95,6 +95,7 @@ The following can be set when running make: make FOO=bar
     DEBUG: disable some optimizations and enable more runtime checking
     HOST_ID_SALT: Optional salt to use when generating host package ids
     BUILD_ID_SALT: Optional salt to use when generating build package ids
+    ALLOW_HOST_PACKAGE: compile using hosts library set (via pkg-config)
comments.body:
Concept ACK.

@skmcontrib 
Could you emphasize that the host's packages are used when they are not built due to the `NO_*` variable set?

Also this line could be moved up to be just under the `NO_UPNP` line.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -95,6 +95,7 @@ The following can be set when running make: make FOO=bar
     DEBUG: disable some optimizations and enable more runtime checking
     HOST_ID_SALT: Optional salt to use when generating host package ids
     BUILD_ID_SALT: Optional salt to use when generating build package ids
+    ALLOW_HOST_PACKAGE: compile using hosts library set (via pkg-config)
comments.body:
```suggestion
    ALLOW_HOST_PACKAGES: compile using hosts library set (via pkg-config)
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -95,6 +95,7 @@ The following can be set when running make: make FOO=bar
     DEBUG: disable some optimizations and enable more runtime checking
     HOST_ID_SALT: Optional salt to use when generating host package ids
     BUILD_ID_SALT: Optional salt to use when generating build package ids
+    ALLOW_HOST_PACKAGE: compile using hosts library set (via pkg-config)
comments.body: Can you please elaborate a bit further what this means? What is compiled using hosts libraries? And which host libraries, which packages are replaced by host packages? When would one want to use this option?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -101,6 +101,10 @@ The following can be set when running make: `make FOO=bar`
 <dd>Don't download/build/cache libs needed to enable the wallet</dd>
 <dt>NO_UPNP</dt>
 <dd>Don't download/build/cache packages needed for enabling upnp</dd>
+<dt>ALLOW_HOST_PACKAGES</dt>
+<dd>Enables the hosts packages in case automatic download/build of dependencies
+is disabled via the NO_* options (example NO_QT etc). This is useful in case of
+cross-compilation (example: compilation for macOS on debian)</dd>
comments.body:
Two notes to consider:
- `NO_PACKAGE` is not the only way to miss package in depends (see #18051, my [previous](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/19124#discussion_r453189380) comment was a bit misleading, sorry for that)
- in general, building with depends is used not only for cross-compilation

```suggestion
<dd>Packages that are missed in dependencies (due to `NO_*` option or
build script logic) are searched for among the host system packages using
`pkg-config`. It allows to build with packages of other (newer) versions</dd>
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -101,6 +101,10 @@ The following can be set when running make: `make FOO=bar`
 <dd>Don't download/build/cache libs needed to enable the wallet</dd>
 <dt>NO_UPNP</dt>
 <dd>Don't download/build/cache packages needed for enabling upnp</dd>
+<dt>ALLOW_HOST_PACKAGES</dt>
+<dd>Enables the hosts packages in case automatic download/build of dependencies
+is disabled via the NO_* options (example NO_QT etc). This is useful in case of
+cross-compilation (example: compilation for macOS on debian)</dd>
comments.body: @hebasto Hopefully I got it right this time. Sorry for being dense and the delay. Appreciate your help and the good learning.
